clinical_study.brief_title: TEDDY - The Environmental Determinants of Diabetes in the Young
clinical_study.official_title: Consortium for Identification of Environmental Triggers of Type 1 Diabetes

lead_sponsor.agency: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases (NIDDK)

collaborator.agency: National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases (NIAID)

clinical_study.source: National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases (NIDDK)

brief_summary.textblock: The long-term goal of the TEDDY study is the identification of infectious agents, dietary factors, or other environmental agents, including psychosocial factors which trigger T1DM in genetically susceptible individuals or which protect against the disease. Identification of such factors will lead to a better understanding of disease pathogenesis and result in new strategies to prevent, delay or reverse T1DM.

primary_outcome.measure: Appearance of one or more islet cell autoantibodies: GADA, IAA, or IA-2A confirmed at two consecutive visits.

arm_group.description: Newborns with high risk HLA in the general population or having a first-degree relative affected with T1DM.

biospec_descr.textblock: Serum, plasma, PBMCs, stool, urine, saliva, nasal swabs, nail clippings, water

study_pop.textblock: Childen up to 4 months of age with specified HLA are enrolled and followed longitudnally until 15 years of age

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Newborns with high risk HLA in the general population or having a first- degree relative affected with T1DM
- Newborns are less than 4 months of age
Exclusion Criteria:
- Have an illness or birth defect that precludes long-term follow-up or involves use of treatment that may alter the natural history of diabetes (e.g. steroids or insulin)
- Refuses to have blood and stool samples stored at the NIDDK Repository
